awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Manufacturing of gallium nitride (GaN) membranes for efficient thermal management
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I seeks to provide gallium nitride (GaN) membranes for the production of semiconductors for numerous applications including power electronics, radio frequency devices, and optoelectronics, etc. The prooposed technology seeks to alleviate two major problems in the current GaN-based manufacturing technology:  thermal management and expensive wafer material costs  - by peeling off the GaN membrane from the parent wafer and integrating it on the heat sink. Integration of thin-film GaN on a heat-sink substrate may solve the intrinsic thermal management issues of GaN-based devices by efficiently dissipating the heat. Commercialization of proposed technology could decrease production costs of GaN-based devices by reusing the expensive parent substrate multiple times while maintain the material quality. Gallium nitride-based technologies have been widely adapted in various fields including healthcare and defense, 5G networks, clean energy applications, electrical vehicles, power inverters and mobile device chargers, etc. 

This project proposes to manufacture the high-quality, free-standing GaN membranes integrated on heat sinks by using two unique technologies: remote epitaxy and 2-dimensional layer transfer (2DLT). Remote epitaxy and 2DLT technologies utilize 2D materials inserted between the substrate and epilayer for the growth and lift-off of GaN thin-film. Combination of remote epitaxy and 2DLT processes allow for the production of high-quality GaN membranes with multiple reuses of costly GaN substrates. Feasibility of proposed technology will be confirmed via time-domain thermoreflectance (TDTR) techniques by measuring the GaN and heat sink interface.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Commercial GaN devices are currently supplied by a broad range of global vendors for their applications in power management, RF and wireless connectivity. Furthermore, investment on the GaN-based technology by various major global companies underline the importance of GaN devices for their application in the automotive, information technology and power supply industries. However, the applications of GaN semiconductor in electronic and optoelectronic device industry has been limited due to the major technical and economic challenges of the high defect density, limited scalability, and expensive production cost. Furthermore, the poor heat dissipation issue during the operation of GaN device resulting from the poor thermal conductance of GaN growth template is still challenging. Future Semiconductor Business (FSB)’s featured technology termed remote epitaxy and 2DLT (2-dimensional layer transfer) process allows to fabricate the free-standing GaN membrane that can be conveniently integrated on customized host substrate. Specifically, this technology provide the unique feature for the numerous GaN based device and system manufacturers to address the above notorious technological issues by heterogeneously integrating the GaN on heat sink.  

Through this SBIR program, FSB developed and demonstrated the advanced manufacturing technology for producing the high-quality free-standing GaN membranes integrated on heat sink for efficient heat management. To demonstrate GaN-on-heat sink, combination of remote epitaxy and 2-dimensional layer transfer (2DLT) process has been employed. The demonstrated manufacturing technology of GaN membranes is beneficial to overcome the thermal management issues in GaN technology leading to immediate advancements in power electronics, optoelectronics, and radio frequency device applications for electric vehicles, display, lighting, and 5G/6G industries. Furthermore, the adoption of GaN membranes provides significant cost savings for the production of GaN based electronics and optoelectronics by reusing the parent wafer after lift-off process. Therefore, FSB believes this project outcome will be the steppingstone for building up the GaN-based semiconductor devices heterointegrated on heat sink to be commercialized as it unlocks the potential pathway to efficiently manage the heat. We believe FSB's technology will contribute to the nation’s qualified advancement in semiconductor industry. 

 


Last Modified: 05/08/2023
Modified by: David S Lee
